awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Distributed Computing with Privacy and Security Considerations
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern datasets have reached such sizes and complexities as to make them difficult to analyze and process using traditional centralized approaches. Distributed computing enables large-scale data processing, by distributing the effort of a computing task over such datasets across a network of machines that operate in parallel. With the proliferation of sensitive data that needs to be processed, and the ever-growing computational power of adversarial parties, ensuring data privacy and security of the computing process represents a critical aspect for the design of modern distributed computing systems. This project aims at developing a theoretical foundation to investigate the performance of distributed computing in the presence of machines that are not trusted or well-protected. This project will promote undergraduate and graduate research, and the outcomes of the proposed research will be integrated into education.

This project considers two different distributed computing scenarios and seeks their theoretical performance limits. In the first scenario, the dataset contains sensitive information (such as clinical/genome information) and, when distributed, has to remain confidential from the machines. An optimization framework is used which seeks to quantify the trade-off between the performance of the computing task and the level of data privacy that can be guaranteed. In the second scenario, the machines may have been compromised and hence may introduce false information to the system. The main focus is on the design of distributed computing techniques that are robust to different message-tampering attacks and allow one to efficiently identify the attacked machines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview. In this project, we worked to design distributed computing techniques that (1) offer the highest performance under data privacy considerations; and (2) are robust to message tampering attacks, under different assumptions on the adversary’s capabilities. Our results (1) allow to  quantify the trade-off between the performance of practically relevant computing tasks (such as, sorting and ranking) and the level of data privacy that can be guaranteed; and (2) demonstrate fundamental performance guarantees of the computing task under different message tampering attacks, and allow to efficiently identify the attacked worker machines.

Intellectual Merit. Several scientific results were discovered and published throughout the course of this project. The technical details can be found inside our publications, as well as in the annual reports of this project. In particular, the major intellectual merits of the project can be summarized as follows. (1) We have considered the task of estimating the ranking of a data vector given a noisy version of it, and established necessary and sufficient conditions on the noise level that ensure that a computationally efficient decoding criterion is optimal (that is, it incurs the minimum probability of error); (2) We have derived fundamental trade-offs between the performance (measured in terms of probability of error) of the ranking estimation task, and the level of privacy that can be guaranteed (using differential privacy) when the noise mechanism consists of adding artificial noise that follows distributions widely used in the privacy literature; (3) We have considered a prevalent computing task in distributed computing, namely matrix multiplication, and derived sufficient conditions that ensure that the master node can successfully recover the result of the computing task with a high probability, in settings where some worker machines are attacked that is, the result of their computation is maliciously perturbed by an adversary; and (4) We have designed suitable mechanisms that allow to identify a set of unattacked worker machines from which the result of the computing task can be successfully recovered with high probability.

Scientific Impact. Our work has contributed to lay the foundation for the design of distributed computing techniques with privacy and security considerations. The project has resulted in 5 published journal publications and 8 conference publications, in venues such as IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Information Theory, IEEE Signal Processing Letters, Transactions on Machine Learning Research, IEEE ISIT and IEEE ITW. The work was also disseminated through several invited talks by the PI, and students supported by this grant.

Broader Impact. Distributed computing is expected to have a significant impact on the societal welfare, for instance in advancing scientific research. This primarily stems from the fact that distributed computing enables performing large-scale data processing. Our work has provided theoretical guarantees on practically relevant computing tasks when the data processed contains confidential information and when computations are susceptible to adversarial attacks. One undergraduate student and two Ph.D. students have worked on parts of this project, and ideas from this project has also been integrated into course projects.
